awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Customer Discovery for a Novel Performance-Enhancing Foot Orthoses
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to address the urgent need of highly durable and more comfortable foot orthoses to benefit military service members and veterans, athletes, as well as other professionals suffering from foot or ankle injuries. The team has developed a nitinol-based foot orthoses. Compared to the current foot orthoses that are made of nonmetallic materials, the nitinol-based foot orthoses can provide enhanced functional capabilities including optimized energy dissipation capacity, improved comfort, long functional life, and lightweight. The life expectancy of the nitinol orthoses is twice as long as that of the plastic orthoses. The foot orthotic insoles market is currently estimated to be worth $2.6B and will grow to $3.7B by 2021. Thus, commercialization and application of the proposed foot orthoses will greatly impact the footwear industry. This project is the beginning of a new science and technology based company that will enhance the technology infrastructure and upon completion provide jobs for the STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) workforce of the state of Mississippi.

This I-Corps project will explore the market potential of the novel foot orthoses previously developed by the team. The foot orthoses are made of nitinol using additive manufacturing methods. Their cellular structure generated during the additive manufacturing process can absorb more shock energy from every step a customer takes, therefore offering adjustable cushioning and comfort to the customer. Due to the shape-memory property and superelasticity of nitinol, the designed foot orthoses are easier to deflect under human body-support interaction forces, and can withstand corrosive environments and fatigue loading conditions. This I-Corps project aims to evaluate the market opportunities of the developed foot orthoses to gain a clear identification of market of the technology, as well as a deeper insight into the needs of potential customers. Discoveries from this project will inform the decision of the next step towards a startup and commercialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The project titled "Customer Discovery and Commercialization for a Novel Performance-Enhancing Foot Orthoses for Military Personnel, Athletes and Others" has now been successfully completed. The PI and the entire project team are grateful for the generous financial support, abundant resources, and outstaning entrepreneurial training offered by Program Directors and I-Corps Instructors through this NSF I-Corps Program. 

In this project, we participated a 7-week I-Corps Temas program, including a 3-day kickoff meeting and a 2-day closing workshop in San Francisco, 6 online classes, and 102 interviews for customer discovery. We also performed some follow-up interviews with military procurement officers after finishing this program. Based on results obtained from the customer discovery interviews we established a new business model. Mean while, we made several prototypes of foot inserts through 3D printing using stainless steel and polymer and conducted initial pilot testing verify the comfort and efficacy of the 3D printed foot inserts.

In terms of intellectural merits, we gained a better understanding of the potential customers, partners, influencers, and markets of the proposed additively manufactured foot orthotics in a complete product ecosystem. The commercial potential of this product was confirmed while the barriers to its full commercialization was identified. A preliminary network with medical device industry professionals was also established through this project. This project has produced 2 journal papers (1 published, 1 under review) and 2 conference papers (both published and presented). 

In terms of the broad impact, this project addresses a longstanding market need for low-cost and durable custom or semi-customized foot orthotic devices to customers with special requirements, which represents an anticipated $8.2B market by 2013. This project also supported one PhD student (the EL) and provided the student with training to become a future leader in innovation and entrepreneurship through the implementation of an educational and leadership development plan. Moreover, the PI presented the outcomes and findings of this project in a seminar to ~60 students who participated in the Entrepreneurship Program at Mississippi State University.    

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2019
Modified by: Yucheng Liu
